newsitem.title: FINLAND: ICE HOCKEY-SWEDEN TAKES ADVANTAGE INTO MEDAL ROUND.
newsitem.headline: ICE HOCKEY-SWEDEN TAKES ADVANTAGE INTO MEDAL ROUND.

text.p: Sweden will carry an unbeaten record and a big advantage into the medal round at the ice hockey world championship after posting a 3-1 win over the United States in their final round-robin match on Saturday.

Russia, the United States, Canada, Finland and the defending champions Czech Republic also qualified but because of a format that allows teams to carry points over, Sweden will already be at least one win up on the others when the medal round begins in Helsinki on Monday.
The United States won three games in pool B but will arrive in Helsinki with no points, as none of victories came against teams that advanced to the medal round.

Hosts Finland were faced with the same fate until they struck five unanswered goals to steal a 7-4 win against previously unbeaten Russia, sending both teams into the next round with two points and within sight of Olympic champions Sweden who moved on with a record of four wins and a tie.
While the United States easily advanced, their chances of claiming their first title in 64 years took a serious blow following their loss to Sweden.
Even Canada, who needed a win in their final match against Italy just to qualify, enter the next round ahead of the Americans.

"Our first goal was obviously to get to the medal round," said U.S. coach Jeff Jackson. "Now we'll just have to take it one game at a time and if the opportunity comes to take points, we'll take them."
Canada secured their place in the medal round with a 6-0 win over Italy.
Needing at least a tie to advance, Canada went to work quickly taking a 2-0 first period lead on goals by Jeff Friesen of the San Jose Sharks and Keith Primeau of the Hartford Whalers.
"Our team was obviously determined to get to Helsinki and play for a medal," said Canadian coach Andy Murray. "Hopefully we're on an upward trend in terms of our play."

The Canadians continued their no nonsense approach in the second as they physically overpowered the smaller Italians, increasing their advantage to 5-0 on goals from Travis Green of the New York Islanders and San Jose Sharks team mates Owen Nolan and Bob Errey.
Dean Evason, the only non-NHL player on the Canadian team, completed the scoring.
In other pool B action, Harius Vitolins scored twice as Latvia beat winless Norway 6-3 to register their first world championship victory as an independent nation since 1939.
In pool A, Martin Prochazka and David Vyborny each scored twice as the Czech Republic hammered France 9-3.
Peter Draisaitl scored with just over five minutes remaining as Germany beat Slovakia 1-0 to register their first win of the tournament.
